intro: Isocoma menziesii var. vernonioides, commonly known as the desert globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its spherical, woolly seed heads that resemble small globes, which are a distinctive botanical feature. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, and it produces yellow flowers in late spring to early summer. This variety is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes mallows and hibiscus.
